formattedAddress: 352 W 39th St, New York, NY 10018, USA
adrFormatAddress: 352 W 39th St, New York, NY 10018, USA

editorialSummary.text: Homey Italian venue serving housemade pastas and other traditional fare in a brick-lined space.

originalText.text:
What a quaint restaurant in the Garment District. We had a lunch reservation prior to a Broadway matinee.

The interior has a very old European vibe.  Service was very professional and attentive. I did think it was odd that they wouldn't serve us the bread until our fourth guest arrived.

Al the food was delicious and ingredients fresh. The serving sizes were appropriate for the price point. Four of us ate for $125 before tip, 4 entrees, 1 wine and 1 coffee.

We arrived at our reservation time and were qseated at a table by the front window. It was fun watching all the people pass by. We were the first in the restaurant at lunch time but as we sat there were several large parties arrived.

There was a plaque on the wall stating it was Michelin rated.

Mercator is an easy walk to the Broadway theaters and worth a visit.

originalText.text: Was there for lunch this Friday and was a litte disappointed. The food was great and the service was good. We were told about the specials and I must say I wanted to try the Puglia food was was swayed by the specials that was mentioned. The butternuts squash soup and the turkey meatballs was very tasty. Regret not checking the price but the young lady mentioned the special but didn’t mention the cost. US$46 for 2 meatballs is a bit more than I would pay. The butternuts squash at US$23 for a fairly large bowl is also too much when the rest of the menu is reasonable priced. My partner’s pasta cost less than the soup. Again my oversight in not checking. But perhaps the staff should inform guests from overseas who may be clueless. I have seen the restaurant many times in my travel to NYC during thanksgiving period but never stepped in. This time I did and I am not sure I will like to go again. I get much value for money in some of the steakhouses in NYC. Service was good but I think the staff need to be upfront and share the cost of the special before it leaves a bitter aftertaste.

originalText.text:
Stopped off here after visiting the edge. Couple from the uk looking for a non mass commercial authentic Italian and we were not disappointed!
We had a few starters… much recommend the spinach and goats cheese side it was amazing!
Mains were also perfect. Husband has monk fish special and I had a lasagne and it just melted in my mouth.
Fantastic service, great atmosphere. Considering the proximity to Times Square the price was also good.
Highly recommend

originalText.text: The food in general is good, but the bruschetta tasted burnt, for my taste, it was not good. The pasta is very al dente, almost raw, to the point where the pasta has hard parts. The gnocci was wonderful! I recommend.

text.text: The food in general is good, but the bruschetta tasted burnt, for my taste, it was not good. The pasta is very al dente, almost raw, to the point where the pasta has hard parts. The gnocci was wonderful! I recommend.

originalText.text: Amazing! I was there a bit early and caught the staff meeting prepping for dinner.  The staff speaking Italian, laughing and having fun was beautiful to hear.  I had the Burrata for appetizer, Spinach Ricotta Ravioli, & Affogato for desert.  All were excellent & the prices reasonable. Reminded me of my Sicilian grandmother's home on Sunday when I was a child. I can't wait to go back and try more!
